taxonomicNotes: Interspecific hybridization of the Pacific Sleeper Shark (S. pacificus) with the Greenland Shark (S. microcephalus) has likely been ongoing at the edges of their distributions since initial divergence (Walter et al. 2017).

This species can be visually distinguished from two morphologically similar regional congeners, the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) and the Gulf of Mexico Smoothhound (M. sinusmexicanus) by several characters including fin shape and ampullary pore patterns (Giresi et al. 2013).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).

This species was described on the basis of specimens collected from Nakagusuku Bay and Haneji Inlet, Okinawa Island, Ryukyu Islands, Japan. Although the present new species has been often misidentified as Acanthopagrus australis (Günther), morphological and genetic evidence showed that it is clearly different from the latter species (Kume and Yoshino 2008, Hsu 2011).
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
This species may have an older name, and because it is black there have probably been many misidentifications. As a result, it may be more widely distributed.
This species is sometimes referred to as Takifugu vermicularis radiatus  in the literature.

Although this species is validated in the Catalog of Fishes, molecular data gathered from analysis of mitochondria and nuclear DNA strongly indicated that T. rubripes and T. pseudommus should be regarded as the same species (Song et al. 2001).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.
The taxonomy of this species and its relationships are poorly-known (Lindeman and Rocha pers. comm. 2011).

Rhynchobatus palpebratus is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

This species is comprised of two valid subspecies: Mustelus canis canis occurs on the continental shelf, whereas M. c. insularis occurs on insular shelves in the Caribbean (Heemstra 1997, Ebert et al. 2013).
Gymnura micrura has been redescribed with G. lessae and G. sereti split out from G. micrura as separate species (Yokota and Carvalho 2017).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Until recently, the species name usually was spelled as sayi rather than say. This is not a synonymy, simply a change to conform to original spelling.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Recent revisions have subdivided the previously wide-ranging Narcine brasiliensis into Narcine bancroftii (Griffith, 1834) which is widely distributed from North Carolina, USA, through parts of the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean Sea, the Greater Antilles, the Lesser Antilles and the northern coast of South America and Narcine brasiliensis (Olfers, 1831) which is endemic to the Southwest Atlantic in Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina (Carvalho 1999, Last et al. 2016).
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists before 2008 under the generic name Papillogobius.
This species has been confused with Raja montagui and Raja polystigma in the Mediterranean Sea (Bertozzi et al. 2003).

Very similar to Prognathus falcifer, which is found in the northern part of the eastern tropical Pacific region. Genetic and morphological studies are needed to confirm whether specifically distinct from P. falcifer.

Previously, this species was included in the genus Tetrapturus (Collette et al. 2006). It is genetically similar to the White Marlin (Kajikia albida), but represents a distinct evolutionary unit (Collette and Graves 2019).
A revision of Scomberomorus was conducted by Collette and Russo (1985).
This species was confused with S. niphonius from Munro (1943) until it was described by Collette and Russo (1980).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). There is confusion with B. vulpinus in New Zealand and probably New South Wales in eastern Austailia.

Identified first as Heterochoerops viridis (Steindachner 1866). A. viridis is considered to be a sibling species of A. gouldii and the two have been generally grouped together as A. gouldii in most of the literature until only fairly recently, i.e ~35 years or so ago (D. Pollard pers. comm. 2008).

Eptatretus burgeri was briefly described by Girard (1855) based on an illustration of a single specimen from Simabara Bay, which was previously misidentified as Heptatrema cirrhatum by Temminck and Schlegel (1850: 310, pl. 143).

There is some potential for confusion with regards the common names of this species. In some areas, Smalleyed Ray may be called Painted Ray or Sandy Ray, though these common names are also used for undulate ray Raja undulata and Leucoraja circularis respectively.

The Green Sturgeon was once considered conspecific with the Sakhalin Sturgeon (Acipenser mikadoi) and the two forms were synonymized (Berg 1948). However, recent molecular data on three mitochondrial genes and morphometric studies show large differences between North American and Asian forms (Birstein and DeSalle 1998, North et al. 2002). Sakhalin Sturgeon is now believed extinct in Japan, Korea and China and the species sustains only a remnant population in Russia's Tumnin River where there is a hatchery (Adams et al. 2002).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

Initial phase closely resembles that of S. maculipinna which occurs further west, from the Mentawai Islands off the Indian Ocean coast of Sumatra to the Andaman Sea (R.F. Myers pers comm. 2009).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008). The sister pair C. bleekeri and C. bowersi share particularly distinctive cheek patches of green/white (C. bleekeri) to solid green/blue (C. bowersi), a double chin strap of blue, and nearly identical fin colourations (Smith et al. 2008). C. troschelii is also likely a member of this clade (Choat and Randall 1986).

It is important to note that there is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with Salmo taxa. Collectively, all nine proposed taxa identified by the IUCN SSC Salmon Specialist Group (SSG) as uncertain—Salmo tigridis, S. platycephalus, S. ischchan, S. abanticus, S. labecula, S. chilo, S. opimus, S. rizeensis, and S. coruhensis—could be considered to fall within what some authors have referred to as the Salmo trutta species complex. This statement means nothing more than the fact that the mtDNA of these taxa would fall within the multiple clades of what sometimes has been simply referred to as Salmo trutta, comprising five or six major mtDNA lineages.  The only Salmo taxa outside of this group of clades (genetically speaking) would be Atlantic Salmon (S. salar), S. belvitca, S. ohridanus and Soft-mouthed Trout (S. obtusirostris). Whereas future higher resolution genetic data (i.e. genomic) will undoubtedly shed more light on the pairwise divergence and  phylogenetic position of these taxa, the SSG sees no evidence, nor has any expectation, that genomic level data will place any of these taxa outside of these major mtDNA lineages.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus. The family name was changed to Epinephelidae by Smith and Craig (2007).
Lupinoblennius dispar has recently been recognised as a junior synonym of L. vinctus (Bath 1996).
There is a possibility that this species is a complex, similar to the Dipturus batis-complex (Iglésias et al. 2010), but further taxonomic work is required.

Dipturus nidarosiensis may be a composite species with a small and large morphotype similar to that seen in Dipturus batis-complex (Iglesias et al. 2010) and Dipturus oxyrinchus-complex. Further genetic research is needed before a taxonomic revision is made, but Dipturus nidarosiensis refers to the larger morphotype and for now the smaller morphotype is referred to as Dipturus sp., as described in the Food and Agricultural Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) catalogue by Ebert and Stehmann (2013).
The validity of the genus Protonibea is uncertain (L. Chao pers. comm. 2019) and therefore the generic-level placement of this species remains in doubt.

The two undescribed species referred to in Last and Stevens (1994) as Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C are considered to be the same species by Last and White (2008) and Last and Stevens (2009), and were described as the Saddled Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium variegatum) by Last and White (2008). However, Last and Stevens (2009) note that the lumping of the tropical and temperate forms of the species (Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C, respectively) is provisional. Their relationship still requires some examination.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus australis to the resurrected and elevated genus Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus cerva to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus endeavouri to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.
This species is often confused with other long-nosed skates.

The taxonomic concept for Hexanchus nakamurai has been revised and Hexanchus vitulus has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Belize, Gulf of Mexico, and Bahamas) (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Previously considered to be restricted to Australia. A recent taxonomic study by White et al. (2015) provided a redescription of the Purple Eagle Ray and the Japanese Eagle Ray (M. tobijei). The results of that study showed that previous records of the Japanese Eagle Ray from Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Okinawa in Japan actually refer to the Purple Eagle Ray. The Japanese Eagle Ray if confined to the western North Pacific, primarily in Japan. Thus, the Purple Eagle Ray's distribution is now extended from Australia north to Taiwan and southern Japan.

Previously this species was included in Squalus sp. C. (= S. altipinnis) (Last and Stevens 1994). It was referred to as Squalus sp. C in Compagno et al. (2005) and as Squalus cf. sp. C in White et al. (2006).
Perca robusta (Couch, 1832) was listed as a synonym of “Epinephelus guaza” (= E. marginatus) by Smith (1971), but Heemstra (1991) considered this latter species a synonym of E. aeneus.

Recent publications have changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007), and the family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007). This species is closely related to Hyporthodus septemfasciatus (known only from Japan, Korea and China) and H. octofasciatus (widespread in the Indo-Pacific region, including in eastern and western Australia, New Zealand and South Africa). The differences between these three species are outlined by Heemstra and Randall (1993). More taxonomic work is needed on this group, especially as it has been proposed that individuals of H. ergastularius recorded in fisheries catches off parts of Queensland may be H. octofasciatus (Pogonoski et al. 2002).
The assessment has been amended in September 2016 to reflect newly available information which places this species in the genus Raja (formally Malacoraja).

Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. The taxonomic validity of this species is in question and requires review. However, until such time as this problem is solved it is treated as a valid species.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae. Petean et al. (2020) revised Hypanus americanus, separating the newly described species, H. berthalutzae, whose distribution includes the Brazilian coastline from the mouth of the Amazon River to São Paulo State.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Previously included within Neotrygon kuhlii, N. australiae was described as a separate species by Last et al. (2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.
The specific name is often misspelled as oxyrhynchus.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

This species was first described by Gubanov and Schleib (1980) but Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) described it as a separate species, Chiloscyllium confusum, without mention of C. arabicum. Compagno (1984) provisionally recognized C. arabicum but noted it was apparently very close to C. punctatum. Dingerkus and DeFino's account clearly establishes this species as separate from C. punctatum (Compagno 2001).

This species has been widely misreported as C. griseum, at least in the Arabian Gulf, and the distribution of these two similar species requires clarification. There is a high need for taxonomic investigation regarding species in the genus Chiloscyllium in the Arabian Sea region (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within the new genus Brevitrygon, previously confused with other dwarf whiprays (Brevitrygon species) (Last et al. 2016b). There remains considerable taxonomic confusion over 'B. walga' with different forms across its range. These may turn out to represent a series of different species.
This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016a).

Until this species' formal description in 2016 (Acero et al. 2016), angel sharks caught in the southern Caribbean were thought to be Squatina dumeril. Further work is needed to determine whether and where the ranges of these two species overlap.

Viana and de Carvalho (2018) propose S. rancureli as a junior synonym of S. melanurus, however the reported differences in colour pattern, morphology and mersitics indicate that further sampling, and a genetic comparison of the two nominal species is needed to support their synonymy. The distributions of Squalus melanurus and S. rancureli also need to be clarified through examination of collected materials. The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.
Dipturus campbelli has previously been incorrectly synonymized with D. pullopunctata (Smith, 1964) by Hulley (1988), but this species is distinct (Compagno et al. 1989, Last et al. 2016).
Finucci et al. (2018) redescribed Chimaera ogilbyi, merging Hydrolagus lemures as a synonym.

Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) synonymized Chiloscyllium caerulopunctatum with C. plagiosum, an action tentatively (and reluctantly) followed by Compagno (2001). The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).

Previously this species was synonymized with Galeus melastomus, but it is now considered a valid species supported by both morphometric external field marks and genetic evidence (Muñoz-Chapuli and Perez-Ortega 1985, Rey et al. 2005, 2006, 2010; Castilho et al. 2007).
The quality of taxonomic identification of some skate species may be an issue particularly with historic data, however, Bathyraja spinicauda is a relatively easy species to identify.
This species is frequently confused with the Bigtail Skate (Dipturus macrocaudus), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. Records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margaritella have included misidentified specimens of the larger sympatric species, F. margarita.
Last et al. (2016a) assigned this species to the recently described genus Orbiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including hortlei).
No taxonomic notes.
Several published works have suggested that Bathyraja smirnovi may be a synonym of B. parmifera. However, B. smirnovi is widely recognised as a valid species (see Dyldin and Orlov 2018).

This species has been previously confused with the Marbled Stingray Dasyatis marmorata and the Common Stingray D. pastinaca, neither of which overlap with the range of the Blue Stingray (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be conspecific with the Speckled Catshark (H. boesemani) but taxonomy has been resolved. Confusion with the Blackspotted Catshark (H. buergeri) possible and referred to in White et al. (2006) as the Indonesian Spotted Catshark (H. cf. buergeri).

Dolganov and Tuponogov (1999) suggest that B. trachouros may be synonymous with B. violacea (Ishihara pers. obs.), however, B. trachouros is treated as a valid species here (clasper structure is distinct) and was recognized as valid by Compagno (2005).

Cephaloscyllium umbratile was recognized as a distinct species by Nakaya (1975). Later, Springer (1979) treated C. umbratile as a junior synonym of C. isabellum. However, recent workers such as Compagno et al. (2005) and Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) treat C. umbratile as a distinct species and Nakaya et al. (2013) also recognized it as a valid species. The sympatric C. formosanum was considered a junior synonym of C. umbratile by Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) but resurrected as a valid species by Nakaya et al. (2013).
This species is frequently confused with the Giant Skate (Dipturus gigas), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).
Squalus acutipinnis is a recently resurrected member of the megalops-cubensis group of Squalus species (Viana and Carvalho 2016). It was previously referred to locally as Squalus megalops.

Dasyatis marmorata is a species occurring off western Africa. This species has often been confused with Dasyatis chrysonota, which is a South African species. However, molecular data supports the non-conspecificity of these two species (Last et al. 2016a).

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.
 
In previous IUCN Red List publications Gymnura marmorata included G. crebripunctata as a synonym. Therefore assessments of G. marmorata from 2012 onwards are not directly comparable with previous assessments under that name.

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.

Even though some previous studies have treated Limia as one of the multiple subgenera in the genus Poecilia (Rosen and Bailey 1963, Meredith et al. 2010, Meredith et al. 2011), several other works have supported the generic classification for Limia (Rodriguez 1997, Hamilton 2001, Poeser 2003, Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). Here we endorse the latter assessment that Limia should be considered a valid, separate genus.

The taxonomic role of genera to express relationships among species is clearly justified in the case of Limia from different points of view. From the biogeographic point of view, species of Limia show a discrete distribution since they are only found in the Antilles, specifically on Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica and the island of Grand Cayman. However, only three species of Poecilia sensu strictu occur in this region and they are restricted exclusively to Hispaniola. In addition, recent phylogenetic analyses have found Limia to be a monophyletic group probably originated from a South American ancestor with the three Hispaniolan Poecilia species mentioned above representing the closest sister group (Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). A very detailed analysis is currently in prep, also confirming Limia as monophyletic (Spikes et al. in prep). Moreover, there is enough morphological distinctiveness in characters with adaptive value such is the case of gonopodial traits to separate species of Limia and Poecilia (Rivas 1978). Furthermore, all of the existing ecological and behavioral literature is using Limia, not Poecilia. Not recognizing Limia as a separate genus from Poecilia may obscure their similarities and cause even more confusion in a group that in fact deserves more taxonomic attention.

This species has been previously misidentified as Sardinella longiceps (Willette and Santos 2013). There may be a second undescribed species in the Philippines similar to S. lemuru (H. Hata unpublished data); however, further research is required for confirmation.

There is some debate over the taxonomic status of separate sub-populations of A. australis in Australia and New Zealand. Based on geographic distribution, geographic differences in vertebral counts and position of dorsal fin insertions, Schmidt (1928) inferred two sub-species. He therefore divided A. australis into A. australis occidentalis in mainland Australia, Tasmania, and Lord Howe Island, and A. australis orientalis distributed in New Zealand. Griffin (1936) renamed the sub-species A. australis australis in Australia and A. australis schmidtii in New Zealand. Ege (1939) retained these names in his revision of the genus Anguilla. Since then, a variety of papers examining the control region of mtDNA (Dijkstra and Jellyman 1999) and the 16S ribosomal RNA domain of mtDNA (Aoyama et al. 2000) suggested a single species. Although, many papers published since indicate both significant morphological (Watanabe et al. 2006) and genetic (Leander et al. 2012, Shen and Tzeng 2007) differences between the two proposed sub-species. At the glass eel stage, they are found to show genetic homogeneity, and it is therefore suggested that the species should be managed cooperatively by Australia and New Zealand as if it were a single population (Jellyman 2007).


The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. australis here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Australia and New Zealand.

According to Parin et al. (2014), conclusions by Vinnikov et al. (2006) and Kartavtsev et al. (2007) that Pseudopleuronectes schrenki is a synonym of P. yokohamae were not fully supported and required further examination of syntypes. Tsukagoshi et al. (2015), based on molecular analyses, concluded these two are separate species. Similarly, Vinnikov et al. (2018), using molecular evidence, concluded that these two nominal species are indeed separate, and likely sister species.
This species is frequently referred to as Tanakius kitaharae or T. kitaharai in the literature, especially in Japan.

Henriques et al. (2014, 2016) used microsatellite makers to show that A. aequidens (sensu lato) included cryptic species – in particular with evidence of two southern African populations, one in South Africa and the other in Angola and Namibia. Subsequently, Song et al. (2017) demonstrated that global Atractoscion comprised four species and that A. aequidens was confined to southern/south-east Africa.

The genus Scoliodon, represented by S. laticaudus, was previously considered monotypic but now consists of three species with S. macrorhynchus resurrected from the junior synonym of S. laticaudus (White et al. 2010).

The Pacific (Thunnus orientalis) and Atlantic (Thunnus thynnus) Bluefin populations are now recognized as separate species (Collette 1999). Thunnus saliens Jordan & Evermann 1926 is a junior synonym of T. orientalis.

The genus Scoliodon, represented by S. laticaudus, was previously considered monotypic but now consists of three species with S. macrorhynchus resurrected from the junior synonym of S. laticaudus (White et al. 2010).

The genus Takifugu speciated and radiated in marine waters around China, Korea, and Japan. The highest species density is found in the Bohai Sea, Yellow Sea, and East China Sea, followed by the Sea of Japan and Pacific Coast of Japan, and finally by the South China Sea. Several species have been reported from the Indian Ocean (Yamanoue et al. 2008).

This species has been confused with its congener the Japanese Wobbegong (Orectolobus japonicus). Species referred to as Orectolobus japonicus are likely a complex of Western Indian Ocean species including this species and the complex requires further taxonomic work (Last et al. 2010a, Last et al. 2010b).

This species of shortfin eel has been proposed to have two subpopulations: one is described as the subspecies Anguilla bicolor bicolor (McClelland 1844), found in the Indian Ocean from the east coast of Africa to northwestern Australia and greater Sundaland; while the other, described as the subspecies Anguilla bicolor pacifica, is found in the West Indo-Pacific from southern China, Philippines and the Indonesian islands of Borneo, Sulawesi and New Guinea (Schmidt 1923). The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. bicolor here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Indian Ocean and West Indo-Pacific.

From a study conducted across the Indonesian archipelago, these proposed subpopulations were found to share many morphological similarities but significant differences in geographic distribution (Sugeha and Suharti 2008). It has been suggested that the two subpopulations share no overlapping continental range (Fahmi 2013). However, A. bicolor from the Indian Ocean has been identified in Malaysia using both morphological and molecular techniques (Arai et al. 2012a, 2015; Hamzah et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017b). More recently A. bicolor from the Indo-pacific has been found to recruit to the Indonesian islands of Java and Sumatera (Sugeha 2019 unpub. data). These indicate an overlap of ranges of the subpopulations. This, as well as almost identical morphological characteristics, suggests molecular techniques are the only fail-safe way to identify the subpopulations (Tanaka et al. 2014, Arai et al. 2015).

Anguilla bicolor is olive to dark bluish-brown dorsally and lighter ventrally from the jaw to the anus. Its dorsal fin soft rays number 240–250 and its anal fin soft rays, 200–220. This species typically has between 103 to 115 vertebrae (Ege 1939, Silfvergrip 2009). It is most easily confused with Anguilla obscura (and its distribution overlaps with this species in New Guinea). It can only be reliably separated from A. obscura by vertebral count (102–108 for A. obscura) (Ege 1939) and/or genetic analyses (Watanabe et al. 2004).

Anguilla mossambica is olive to greyish black dorsally and lighter ventrally, with the caudal fin confluent with the dorsal and anal fin (Froese and Pauly 2011). It has been suggested that this species and A. borneensis could be basal species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005, Fahmi 2015).

Anguilla bengalensis has an elongate body and a conical head that is dorsally flattened. It has prominent thick lips and narrow bands of teeth on the jaws and is often difficult to distinguish from Anguilla marmorata. Some intraspecific variation has been observed within A. bengalensis to the extent that some authors (e.g., Ege 1939, Watanabe et al. 2014) refer to two subpopulations: one described as Anguilla bengalensis bengalensis commonly found in countries of the Indian Ocean region; and the other A. bengalensis labiata (African Mottled Eel) which occurs in Eastern Africa and as a vagrant in the Arabian Peninsula. The two subpopulations are considered synonyms of A. bengalensis here, though this observed intraspecific variation is noted for the purposes of regionally specific conservation planning for the two subpopulations in the Indian Ocean and in Africa. Several other regional synonyms for this species are known from specimens in Asia and Africa.

The most important parameter for distinguishing between A. bengalensis and A. marmorata is the distance between the origins of the dorsal fin and the anus (ano-dorsal % of TL). Typically, in A. bengalensis this feature is 10.5–12.5% of the total length, for A. marmorata it is 15.5–16.5% (Silfvergrip 2009). This species has between 106 and 115 vertebrae (Silfvergrip 2009).
Previously a junior synonym of the Striped Panray (Zanobatus schoenleinii), this species has larger thorns on the upper disc and a more heavily spotted disc (Last et al. 2016).
Raja parva was split from Raja miraletus in 2016 (Last and Séret 2016).

The newly described species differs from congeneric North Pacific species (S. mitsukurii and S. japonicus) in having fewer vertebrae, larger dorsal fin bases with a shorter interdorsal space, and a more posterior origin of the pelvic fins (Dolganov 2019, Viana and Carvalho 2020).

The newly described Hemiscyllium michaeli Allen & Dudgeon, 2010 has been split from H. freycineti. As such, H. freycineti is now considered to be restricted to western New Guinea, whereas H. michaeli occurs in eastern New Guinea (Allen et al. 2016).
Until Bathyraja cousseauae was described recently, this was often identified as B. brachyurops.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted; a revision is underway with the Ph.D. thesis of Jimena San Martin.

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864
